terms.definition: Movement of a body part away from the midline of the body. For example, lifting your arm out to the side is shoulder abduction.
Movement of a body part toward the midline of the body. The opposite of abduction.
The range of movement at a joint that a person can achieve using their own muscle power, without external assistance.
Decrease in size or wasting away of muscle tissue, often due to disuse, injury, or disease.
The ability to maintain the body's center of mass over its base of support. Essential for standing, walking, and all functional activities.
The study of mechanical laws relating to the movement and structure of living organisms. Important for understanding how the body moves.
Pain that persists beyond the normal healing time, typically defined as lasting more than 3-6 months.
Permanent shortening of a muscle or joint that limits normal movement. Can result from prolonged immobility or spasticity.
Movement that brings the top of the foot closer to the shin. The opposite of plantarflexion.
Swelling caused by excess fluid trapped in the body's tissues. Common after injury or surgery.
Movement that increases the angle between body parts. For example, straightening the knee is knee extension.
Movement that decreases the angle between body parts. For example, bending the elbow is elbow flexion.
The manner or pattern of walking. Gait analysis is used to identify abnormalities and guide treatment.
Increase in the size of muscle fibers, typically resulting from strength training.
The body's protective response to injury or infection, characterized by redness, heat, swelling, and pain.
Exercise where the muscle contracts without changing length. For example, pushing against a wall.
Passive movement techniques applied to joint surfaces to restore normal motion and reduce pain.
The study of human movement. Forms the foundation of physiotherapy practice.
Tough band of fibrous tissue that connects bones to other bones at a joint.
Hands-on treatment techniques used by physiotherapists to treat muscle and joint conditions.
The continuous passive partial contraction of muscles at rest. Abnormal tone can be hypertonic (too high) or hypotonic (too low).
The brain's ability to reorganize itself by forming new neural connections. Key concept in neurological rehabilitation.
Degenerative joint disease characterized by breakdown of cartilage. The most common form of arthritis.
The range of movement at a joint achieved with external assistance, without active muscle contraction.
Movement that points the toes downward, like pressing a gas pedal. The opposite of dorsiflexion.
Movement that points the toes downward, like pressing a gas pedal. The opposite of dorsiflexion.
The body's ability to sense its position and movement in space without visual input. Important for balance and coordination.
The full movement potential of a joint, usually measured in degrees.
The process of restoring function and quality of life after injury, illness, or surgery.
A condition in which muscles have increased tone, causing stiffness and difficulty with movement. Common after stroke or spinal cord injury.
Tough band of fibrous tissue that connects muscle to bone, transmitting the force of muscle contraction.
Exercise prescribed to address specific impairments and achieve therapeutic goals.
Use of sound waves to treat soft tissue injuries by promoting healing and reducing inflammation.
The sensory system in the inner ear that contributes to balance and spatial orientation.
The amount of body weight that can be placed through a limb. Often modified after injury or surgery.
